Problem:
Consider a function \\( z(t) \\) representing a complex-valued signal over time. The function is transformed by a Fourier transform, represented as \\( \\hat{z}(\\omega) = \\int_{-\\infty}^{\\infty} z(t) e^{-i\\omega t} dt \\). We analyze causal inference when altering the frequency spectrum by filtering specific frequency components.

After observing a time-domain signal \\( z'(t) \\) obtained from an inverse Fourier transform of a filtered spectrum, can we perfectly reconstruct the unaltered original signal \\( z(t) \\) without prior knowledge of the applied filter?
Explanation: Without knowing the details of the frequency components removed by the filter, it is impossible to accurately reconstruct the original signal since the high-frequency details lost during filtering are irreplaceable. Hence, perfect reconstruction of \\( z(t) \\) from the altered \\( z'(t) \\) is not feasible.

causal_map_integration: The original signal z(t) is transformed into its frequency spectrum \\hat{z}(\\omega) through the Fourier transform. This frequency spectrum is then altered by applying a filter, resulting in a filtered spectrum. The filtered spectrum is used to obtain a new time-domain signal z'(t) via the inverse Fourier transform.
